items.title: South Korea to compile transcript of voice recording from crashed plane on Saturday
items.description: Investigators on Saturday expect to compile the complete transcript from the cockpit voice recorder recovered from the wreckage of the Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 that crashed on Sunday in South Korea,...

items.title: Guess Who's Building America's New Doomsday Plane?
items.author: Rich Smith
items.description: The U.S. Navy awarded Northrop Grumman a $3.5 billion contract to build E-130J 'Doomsday Planes' for use in a nuclear war. While the contract is significant, Northrop's aeronautics division is its least profitable, and the stock is already expensive.

insights.sentiment_reasoning: The article notes that the $3.5 billion contract is not particularly large, amounting to only 3% of Northrop's annual aeronautics sales. Additionally, the aeronautics division is the company's least profitable, and the stock is already trading at a high valuation, suggesting the contract alone is not enough to significantly move the needle on the stock price.
Lockheed Martin is mentioned as a subcontractor on the E-130J project, but the article does not provide any specific commentary on the impact of this contract on Lockheed Martin.
RTX Corporation is also mentioned as part of Northrop's team for the E-130J project, but the article does not provide any further details on the impact for RTX.

The article notes that the U.S. Air Force's Doomsday Planes, the E-4B Nightwatch, were previously built by Boeing, but a new $13.1 billion contract to replace them was awarded to Sierra Nevada Corporation, with Boeing losing its role as the prime contractor.
